response: The slide is prompting the audience to consider the behavior of water in real-life scenarios. It notes that in natural conditions, water would spill over edges when there are no boundaries to contain it. However, when there is a bounded area such as a contained space or structure, the water will be trapped within that area. This analogy is likely provided to help the audience visualize and understand the concept of water trapping or retention in the context of the upcoming discussion or problem-solving task.

prompt:

but if there is a bounded area,
the water will get trapped in it. From real life   If we pure water from the left of the scene.
The water will fill the deepest regions first,
then the water will fill up to the top.

When the water level reaches the bound.
the water will spill over and will continue to the right.
response: The slide is using a real-life analogy to explain the concept of water trapping within bounded areas. It describes how, in a physical scenario, when water is poured into a confined space from the left side, it will naturally flow towards and fill the deepest areas first before rising to the top level. Once the water level reaches the boundaries of the container, any additional water will spill over and continue flowing to the right. This analogy helps in understanding the process of water distribution and containment within limited spaces before overflowing occurs.
